newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia sees 1997 grain imports of 3.5-4 mln tonnes.
newsitem.headline: Russia sees 1997 grain imports of 3.5-4 mln tonnes.

text.p: Russian Agriculture Minister Viktor Khlystun said on Friday that Russia's total grain imports for 1997 would be 3.5-4.0 million tonnes.

"We will buy 3.5 to four million tonnes of all kinds of grains and pulses," he told a news conference. He did not name the countries from which Russia would buy grain, but he said all buying would be done by the private sector. He also said that Russia's food wheat exports this year would be four million tonnes while its feed wheat exports would be six million tonnes.

"We can export four million tonnes of food wheat and six million tonnes of feed wheat, so our export potential is 10 million tonnes," Khlystun said, adding later, "I can't say from which countries we will import, because it will be through commercial structures."

Russia's annual grain export potential in the coming years was 10 million tonnes, he said. Recovery in the livestock sector, requiring more feed grains, would be accompanied by increased grain output.
